data.title: Yippie! (and other 60s history)
data.meta_description: The Yippies were a revolutionary political party in the 60s, the president was Jerry Rubin. Jerry Rubin was very outspoken, but also constantly working with...
data.text:
The Yippies were a revolutionary political party in the 60s, the president was Jerry Rubin. Jerry Rubin was very outspoken, but also constantly working with strong opposition, when he wasn't doing bad things at all.

[ame="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=58U8QSO0bto"]Rubin (Part 1) - YouTube[/ame]

[ame="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OgeonR275aA"]Yippies For Nixon - YouTube[/ame]

In my opinion the Yippies were one of the few white revolutionary parties that really DID anything in the 60s.

Another well known leader of the group (more well known than Jerry) was Abbie Hoffman. Not many people have learned about who this group is, or what they did, but you have no doubt heard of at least one of their protests.

There was one famous protest (though they protested and were on national TV all the time) was at the pentagon. The Yippies sent out flyers that claimed they were going to "meditate" and make the pentagon "levitate". They surrounded the pentagon with military opposition, put flowers in the barrels of their guns, and hung out for a while.

They also started a famous riot at the Democratic national convention.

And Abbie Hoffman went on stage during Woodstock and suggested that everyone go to the prison and break out their brothers and sisters. But the who was on stage and hit him with guitars until he left.

He was on trial with what I believe was known as the "Chicago 7" for starting riots.

The Yippies were a revolutionary political party in the 60s, the president was Jerry Rubin. Jerry Rubin was very outspoken, but also constantly working with strong opposition, when he wasn't doing bad things at all.

Rubin (Part 1) - YouTube

Yippies For Nixon - YouTube

In my opinion the Yippies were one of the few white revolutionary parties that really DID anything in the 60s.

Another well known leader of the group (more well known than Jerry) was Abbie Hoffman. Not many people have learned about who this group is, or what they did, but you have no doubt heard of at least one of their protests.

There was one famous protest (though they protested and were on national TV all the time) was at the pentagon. The Yippies sent out flyers that claimed they were going to "meditate" and make the pentagon "levitate". They surrounded the pentagon with military opposition, put flowers in the barrels of their guns, and hung out for a while.

They also started a famous riot at the Democratic national convention.

And Abbie Hoffman went on stage during Woodstock and suggested that everyone go to the prison and break out their brothers and sisters. But the who was on stage and hit him with guitars until he left.

He was on trial with what I believe was known as the "Chicago 7" for starting riots.

The history of the 60s was a time distorted by chaos and opposition. It often called the time of troubles by people in the establishment and a rite of passage for a huge generation suddenly coming of age, "The Baby Boomers."

Every new generation is going to defy the parent generation and this one did with joyful exuberance.

To say that Rubin and Hoffman were the only good things to come out of the decade is just not looking very closely.

The society of the 50's was rigidly conformist. If you stood in Times Square on any day, almost every male wore a white shirt and tie and maybe a suit jacket and hard leather shoes. Women didn't wear pants and there was a lot less of them because the majority of them were "homemakers or housewives."

The 60's dramatically changed all of this. A young generation was set free in a prosperous time where you could hitch-hike all over the country or go to the big city with not much more than $20 in your pocket. The only way you could do that today would be as an outlaw or a homeless person.

The 50's were so heavily censored that this new generation rejected many of the old traditions to the point where they began to invent their own life styles. For many this included drugs.

People forget that women were not liberated at this time. There was an implied social code that they were supposed to follow. The 60's prosperity brought in a time where women could go to college and forge a career. They could get their own apartment and not be exclusively dependent on a male and certainly not stay in an abusive relationship as in the past.

People forget how it was before.

Homosexuals were regularly jailed or black-mailed. In some states, blacks could not legally marry whites under threat of prison or worse.

The democratic tradition of protest came alive in opposition to the war in Vietnam and was instrumental in ending the war.

People tend to characterize the 60's as, ..Dirty hippies, drugs and chaos in the streets." They over look the important, positive social changes that occurred during this time and that we now take for granted.

There was one famous protest (though they protested and were on national TV all the time) was at the pentagon. The Yippies sent out flyers that claimed they were going to "meditate" and make the pentagon "levitate". They surrounded the pentagon with military opposition, put flowers in the barrels of their guns, and hung out for a while.

They also started a famous riot at the Democratic national convention.

...

He was on trial with what I believe was known as the "Chicago 7" for starting riots.

To me, the Chicago 7 trial was more interesting than what they did before.

The main charge, IIRC, was not just starting a riot, but conspiracy to cross state lines to start a riot. That made it federal case.

Throughout the trial, many of the 7, including Hoffman & Ruben, kept up their 'theatrical' antics, often turning the court into a circus. At the same time, the judge, Julius Hoffman, played a hard-... denying certain rights to the defendants and making other slanted rulings. In the end, most, if not all of the 7 were convicted of one thing or another and sentence to prison. But the Supreme Court overturned the ruling and set them free.

Years ago HBO made a very good reenactment movie of the trial culled directly from the court records. I don't know if it is still available. But it casts serious doubts on the 7 starting the riots. it seems closer to the truth to say that the Chicago police were the main culprits.
